page.title:
The SAM-Grid Project
The SAM-Grid Project
page.enlisting:
Mission: enable fully distributed computing for DZero and CDF Strategy: enhance the distributed data handling system of the experiments (SAM), incorporating standard Grid tools and protocols, and developing new solutions for Grid computing (JIM) History: SAM from 1997, JIM from end of 2001 Funds: received some funding from the Particle Physics Data Grid (US) and GridPP (UK) People: Computer scientists and Physicists from Fermilab and the collaborating Institutions
Mission: enable fully distributed computing for M i s s i o n : e n a b l e f u l l y d i s t r i b u t e d c o m p u t i n g f o r
DZero and CDF
Strategy: enhance the distributed data handling S t r a t e g y : e n h a n c e t h e d i s t r i b u t e d d a t a h a n d l i n g
system of the experiments (SAM), incorporating
standard Grid tools and protocols, and developing
new solutions for Grid computing (JIM)
History: SAM from 1997, JIM from end of 2001 H i s t o r y : S A M f r o m 1 9 9 7 , J I M f r o m e n d o f 2 0 0 1
Funds: received some funding from the Particle F u n d s : r e c e i v e d s o m e f u n d i n g f r o m t h e P a r t i c l e
Physics Data Grid (US) and GridPP (UK)
People: Computer scientists and Physicists from P e o p l e : C o m p u t e r s c i e n t i s t s a n d P h y s i c i s t s f r o m
Fermilab and the collaborating Institutions

page.title:
What is SAM-Grid used for?
What is SAM-Grid used for?
page.normal_text:
Montecarlo production for DZero
Montecarlo production for DZero

From March 2004 produced > 2,000,000 events, equivalent to 11 yrs GHz computation Other Activities:
From March 2004 produced > 2,000,000
events, equivalent to 11 yrs GHz
computation
Other Activities:

Extending the infrastructure to enable data reconstruction for DZero Montecarlo production for CDF at the prototypical stage
Extending the infrastructure to enable data
reconstruction for DZero
Montecarlo production for CDF at the
prototypical stage

page.title:
The Deployment Phase
The Deployment Phase
page.enlisting:
The initial deployment took 3 months: Jan - Mar 2004 The inefficiencyin event production due to the grid infrastructure improved from 40% to 1-5%
The initial deployment took 3 months:
Jan - Mar 2004
The inefficiencyin event production due
to the grid infrastructure improved from
40% to 1-5% Inefficiency of the infrastructure = 1 - (events produced / events requested)
Inefficiency of the infrastructure =
1 - (events produced / events requested)
This talk focuses on the main sources inefficiencies and how we mitigated them
This talk focuses on the main sources
inefficiencies and how we mitigated
them

page.title:
The Deployment Model
The Deployment Model
page.normal_text:
Every site provides a gateway node where experts + local contacts can install the SAM-Grid software:
Every site provides a gateway node
where experts + local contacts can
install the SAM-Grid software:
page.enlisting:
Standard middleware (VDT), Grid/Fabric interface, VO Services client code VO-specific services run at the site: SAM, JIM Monitoring, Local Scheduler, Local Storage No software/daemon required at the worker nodes of the cluster Standard middleware (VDT), Grid/Fabric interface, VO Services client code VO-specific services run at the site: SAM, JIM Monitoring, Local Scheduler, Local Storage
Standard middleware (VDT), Grid/Fabric
interface, VO Services client code
VO-specific services run at the site:
SAM, JIM Monitoring, Local Scheduler,
Local Storage
No software/daemon required at the worker nodes of the cluster
No software/daemon required at the
worker nodes of the cluster

page.title:
Status of the Deployment
Status of the Deployment
page.enlisting:
A dozen institutions currently part of the grid ~50% stable enough to be used for production US Institutions
A dozen institutions currently part of
the grid
~50% stable enough to be used for
production
US Institutions FNAL, UW Madison, UTA, LUHEP, LTU, OSCER, OUHEP Non-US Institutions
FNAL, UW Madison, UTA, LUHEP, LTU,
OSCER, OUHEP
Non-US Institutions
IN2P3 (Fr), Oxford (UK), Manchester (UK), Prague (Cz), GridKa (De), Sprace (Br)
IN2P3 (Fr), Oxford (UK), Manchester (UK),
Prague (Cz), GridKa (De), Sprace (Br)

page.title:
The Operation/Support Model
The Operation/Support Model
page.enlisting:
A few production users can submit from their laptop to any SAM-Grid site The software at each site is uniformand adapts to the local fabric configuration The JIM infrastructure is currently maintained by 1 FTE + local contacts.
A few production users can submit from their
laptop to any SAM-Grid site
The software at each site is uniformand
adapts to the local fabric configuration
The JIM infrastructure is currently maintained
by 1 FTE + local contacts. This improves the previous model, where an expert per site was necessary to maintain the specific local production mechanisms
This improves the previous model, where an
expert per site was necessary to maintain the
specific local production mechanisms

page.title:
System Configuration Problems 1
System Configuration Problems 1
page.normal_text:
1. Time synchronization of the worker
1. Time synchronization of the worker

nodes
nodes

The Grid Security Infrastructure relies on the machine clock to determine the validity of the security tokens Administrators: please run ntpd ! We also introduced artificial delays at the worker nodes to avoid “Proxy not yet valid” errors
The Grid Security Infrastructure relies on
the machine clock to determine the
validity of the security tokens
Administrators: please run ntpd !
We also introduced artificial delays at the
worker nodes to avoid “Proxy not yet w o r k e r
n o d e s
t o
a v o i d
“ P r o x y
n o t
y e t
valid” errors v a l i d ”
e r r o r s

page.title:
System Configuration Problems 2
System Configuration Problems 2
page.normal_text:
2. The Black Hole effect
2. The Black Hole effect

Even if a single node in the cluster is mis-configured and makes its jobs crash, the batch system keeps sending idle jobs to it: the whole queue of jobs will crash. 3. The Batch System does not immediately show up
Even if a single node in the cluster is mis-configured and
makes its jobs crash, the batch system keeps sending idle
jobs to it: the whole queue of jobs will crash.
3. The Batch System does not immediately show up

the jobs submitted to it or it times out
the jobs submitted to it or it times out

When the Grid asks the status of the jobs and cannot find them, it thinks that they are finished: resource leak!
When the Grid asks the status of the jobs and cannot find
them, it thinks that they are finished: resource leak!

Both problems have been solved writing an “idealizer” (level of abstraction) in front of the batch system. In this code we can exclude statistically bad nodes, retry polling commands, etc.
Both problems have been solved writing an
“idealizer” (level of abstraction) in front of the
batch system. In this code we can exclude
statistically bad nodes, retry polling commands,
etc.

page.title:
System Configuration Problems 3
System Configuration Problems 3
page.enlisting:
4. The worker nodes do not know their 5. Running gridftp transfers between worker and head node within a private networkis tricky 4. The worker nodes do not know their
4. The worker nodes do not know their
5. Running gridftp transfers between worker and head node within a private networkis tricky
5. Running gridftp transfers between worker
and head node within a private networkis
tricky
domain name
domain name
Our infrastructure wants to know… is this really SAM-Grid specific?
Our infrastructure wants to know… is this really
SAM-Grid specific?
Gridftp works in active mode only: the server at the head node may not be able to open the port to the client at the worker node Solution: give the head node a private network interface
Gridftp works in active mode only: the server at
the head node may not be able to open the port
to the client at the worker node
Solution: give the head node a private network
interface

page.title:
System Configuration Problems 4
System Configuration Problems 4
page.enlisting:
“We upgraded the worker nodes to RH9 and forgot to tell you…” 6. Plan the OS upgrades with the system administrators… or be resilient to it 7. Negotiate/Study the policy limits “We upgraded the worker nodes to RH9 and forgot to tell you…”
“We upgraded the worker nodes to RH9
and forgot to tell you…”
6. Plan the OS upgrades with the system administrators… or be resilient to it 7. Negotiate/Study the policy limits 6. Plan the OS upgrades with the system administrators… or be resilient to it
6. Plan the OS upgrades with the system
administrators… or be resilient to it
7. Negotiate/Study the policy limits
7. Negotiate/Study the policy limits
Jobs have been killed or slowed down by batch system CPU limits, data handling file transfers limits, probability of job preemption ~1, …
Jobs have been killed or slowed down by
batch system CPU limits, data handling
file transfers limits, probability of job
preemption ~1, …

page.title:
Gateway and VO Problems
Gateway and VO Problems
page.enlisting:
Most of our work went in the interface between the Grid and the Fabric The standard Globus job-managers are not sufficiently… …flexible: they expect a “standard” batch system configuration. None of our sites was that standard. …scalable: a process per grid job is started up at the gateway machine. We want/need aggregation. …comprehensive: they interface to the batch system only. How about data handling, local monitoring, databases, etc. …robust: if the batch system forgets about the jobs, they cannot react. We have written the “idealizers” for this. To address these issues we had to write a “thick” Grid/Fabric interface (jim-job-manager). The drawback of this approach is that it complicates the local configuration. Most of our work went in the interface between the Grid and the Fabric The standard Globus job-managers are not sufficiently…
Most of our work went in the interface between the
Grid and the Fabric
The standard Globus job-managers are not
sufficiently…
…flexible: they expect a “standard” batch system configuration. None of our sites was that standard. …scalable: a process per grid job is started up at the gateway machine. We want/need aggregation. …comprehensive: they interface to the batch system only. How about data handling, local monitoring, databases, etc. …robust: if the batch system forgets about the jobs, they cannot react. We have written the “idealizers” for this. To address these issues we had to write a “thick” Grid/Fabric interface (jim-job-manager). The drawback of this approach is that it complicates the local configuration.
…flexible: they expect a “standard” batch system
configuration. None of our sites was that standard.
…scalable: a process per grid job is started up at the
gateway machine. We want/need aggregation.
…comprehensive: they interface to the batch system only.
How about data handling, local monitoring, databases, etc.
…robust: if the batch system forgets about the jobs, they
cannot react. We have written the “idealizers” for this.
To address these issues we had to write a “thick”
Grid/Fabric interface (jim-job-manager). The
drawback of this approach is that it complicates the
local configuration.

page.title:
Grid Services Problems 1
Grid Services Problems 1
page.normal_text:
Scalability of the semi-central services
Scalability of the semi-central services

access to the central data handling database is organized in a 3-tiers architecture the middle tier couldn’t cope with 200 jobs starting up at the same time, asking for data we had to introduce retrials with exponential back off to mitigate the problem. We also aggregate access from the gateway node for the information that is common to all processes.
access to the central data handling database is
organized in a 3-tiers architecture
the middle tier couldn’t cope with 200 jobs
starting up at the same time, asking for data
we had to introduce retrials with exponential back
off to mitigate the problem. We also aggregate
access from the gateway node for the information
that is common to all processes.

page.title:
Grid Services Problems 2
Grid Services Problems 2
page.normal_text:
Firewalls: understand the network topology of your grid
Firewalls: understand the network
topology of your grid

System administrators generally are willing to open ports to a certain list of nodes when the software is installed Maintaining the configuration up to date as new installation are deployed is difficult For core services, such as data movement, the SAM-Grid can route data via delegation if direct transfers are not possible
System administrators generally are willing
to open ports to a certain list of nodes
when the software is installed
Maintaining the configuration up to date as
new installation are deployed is difficult
For core services, such as data movement,
the SAM-Grid can route data via delegation
if direct transfers are not possible

page.title:
Conclusions
Conclusions
page.enlisting:
The SAM-Grid is an integrated grid system for job, data and information management for HEP It is used in “production” for DZero montecarlo since March 2004.
The SAM-Grid is an integrated grid system for job,
data and information management for HEP
It is used in “production” for DZero montecarlo since
March 2004. We are working on data reconstruction for DZero and montecarlo generation for CDF
We are working on data reconstruction for DZero and
montecarlo generation for CDF
During deployment and operations we had to overcome problems at the level of
During deployment and operations we had to
overcome problems at the level of
the systems: careful administration is crucial the Grid/Fabric interface: we need a “thick” interface the Grid services: be careful about scalability and network topology
the systems: careful administration is crucial
the Grid/Fabric interface: we need a “thick” interface
the Grid services: be careful about scalability and network
topology
